577.text:
>> Doug Orr: Good morning
and be seated everyone.

584.text:
I'm Doug Orr and I have
the honor of serving

587.text:
as interim chancellor at this
wonderful university. Welcome to

593.text:
the December Commencement, and I
would say celebration, for The

597.text:
University of North Carolina at
Asheville. We are delighted

602.text:
to welcome so many families who
are here to join us, coming from

607.text:
all over, for this special
occasion. Graduates, here you

611.text:
are. It's been a winding road
for many. And here you are today

616.text:
for this celebration. You have
been successful in achieving

620.text:
this significant goal - a
university degree. You have met

626.text:
your own expectations as well as
those of your family and

628.text:
friends. So what now? Frequently
at commencement ceremonies,

637.text:
there will be someone who asks
you about what your next job is.

643.text:
And perhaps, maybe, you'll
change the world. That's a

648.text:
powerful expectation for sure,
and at first sounds incredibly

653.text:
impossible, doesn't it? But each
of you, in your own way, will

659.text:
change the world. The noted
anthropologist Jane Goodall, who

665.text:
once spoke here in Asheville,
said, “Every individual matters.

671.text:
Every individual has a role to
play. Every individual makes a

681.text:
been especially impressed by the
heroics of people convinced they

684.text:
are about to change the world. I
am more awed by those who

694.text:
that's the secret. To change the
world you only need to make such

699.text:
a difference. Sometimes it means
being different - speaking out,

705.text:
standing up - going against the
norm. Sometimes it takes courage

711.text:
and strength. But you can do it.
You have done it. In part

717.text:
because your education here at
UNC Asheville emphasized that.

722.text:
Your individuality. Your
wholeness. You have learned the

727.text:
value of creative debate; how to
take an opposing view, for

731.text:
example. In your class, in your
dorm, with your friends. You can

739.text:
look at something from several
points of view and we invite you

741.text:
do that for the future and get
excited about the possibilities

745.text:
of a new approach. And you have
honed your powers of persuasion

750.text:
so that you can work
collaboratively in partnership

754.text:
with others and multiply the
opportunities for greater

757.text:
change. Each one of you can be
the spark, the one person who

763.text:
starts something new. And that
new thing - whatever it may be -

768.text:
can indeed change the world.
Anne Frank, that courageous

774.text:
young woman, wrote in her diary,
“How wonderful it is that nobody

780.text:
need wait a single moment before
starting to improve the world.”

788.text:
And, speaking of a single
moment, I love this quotation

791.text:
from Benjamin Mays who was a
minister to Dr. Martin Luther

796.text:
King. It's called “God's
Minute.” “I only have a minute,

802.text:
only 60 seconds in it. Placed
upon me, can't refuse it. Didn't

807.text:
seek it, didn't choose it. But
it's up to me to use it. I must

814.text:
suffer if I lose it, give
account if I abuse it.  Just a

817.text:
tiny little minute, but eternity
is in it.” May we proceed to

824.text:
savor these very special moments
of a lifetime. So please stand

830.text:
now as Michelle Arielle McIntyre
will lead us in the national

847.text:
O say can you
see by the dawn's early light,

860.text:
What so proudly we hailed at the
twilight's last gleaming, Whose

871.text:
broad stripes and bright stars
through the perilous fight, O'er

884.text:
the ramparts we watched, were so
gallantly streaming? And the

894.text:
rockets' red glare, the bombs
bursting in air, Gave proof

906.text:
through the night that our flag
was still there; O say does that

918.text:
star-spangled banner yet wave,
O'er the land of the free and

928.text:
star-spangled banner yet wave,
O'er the land of the free and

959.text:
It is now my distinct
pleasure to welcome

963.text:
Joan MacNeill, a distinguished
member of the Board of

967.text:
Governors and the liaison from
the UNC Board of Governors

972.text:
to this fine university to
bring greetings

975.text:
from the University of North
Carolina system. She will be

979.text:
followed by King Prather, Chair
of the UNC Asheville Board of

984.text:
Trustees to then bring you
greetings from the Board.

1000.text:
Chancellor Orr. And thank you
for your very wise, dedicated,

1005.text:
and enthusiastic service as our
interim Chancellor. To today's

1011.text:
graduates and their families, to
our alumni, to Chancellor Orr,

1018.text:
the Board of Trustees, and to
this University's distinguished

1022.text:
faculty and staff, I bring
greetings, congratulations and

1030.text:
well wishes from the University
of North Carolina President Tom

1034.text:
Ross, the UNC General
Administration, and the chairman

1040.text:
John Fennebresque, and all of
the members of the University of

1045.text:
North Carolina Board of
Governors. That's a lot of

1049.text:
folks. But I absolutely know
that each and every one of them

1054.text:
is tremendously proud of you and
wish you great success. You have

1061.text:
such good reason to be very
proud today. Your university,

1067.text:
the University of North Carolina
Asheville has an exceptional

1072.text:
reputation for teaching and
academic excellence. UNC

1078.text:
Asheville is ranked one of the
very best public liberal arts

1083.text:
universities in America. Your
school plays an extensive role

1090.text:
in this community and is one of
the region's greatest assets.

1096.text:
Your liberal arts education at
UNC Asheville has provided you

1103.text:
with the tools for achieving
success in these ever-changing,

1108.text:
complex times and will serve you
very well as you go forward in

1116.text:
your world of work, family and
community. Graduates, I want to

1122.text:
ask, that you take a moment. I
think it's appropriate and would

1126.text:
be a good time to just take a
deep breath and reflect on all

1133.text:
that you have achieved. This
ceremony is a celebration of

1139.text:
your commitment, your time, your
energy, and yes, your passion.

1144.text:
You have made it! And it is my
guess it wasn't always easy. It

1150.text:
probably took a lot of hard work
and a few all nighters. I

1154.text:
remember those. Trying to meet
those deadlines for papers and

1159.text:
preparing for exams. So today,
when you take that moment of

1164.text:
reflection, I ask you to think
about saying thank you to those

1170.text:
who supported you along the
way. The faculty and staff who

1175.text:
nurtured and guided you. Your
parents, family, and friends who

1182.text:
stood by you when you needed
encouragement. You have proven

1186.text:
that you have what it takes to
make a success of anything you

1190.text:
set out to achieve. And as you
look forward and chart your

1194.text:
course to build on what you have
learned here. There's one thing

1198.text:
that we ask that you: Remember
the meaning of this day and

1204.text:
always stay connected to this
great university. We know

1209.text:
you will make us proud of your
accomplishments in the days and

1224.text:
>> King Prather: Good morning.
On behalf of the UNC Asheville

1228.text:
Board of Trustees, it is my
pleasure to bring greetings to

1231.text:
our graduates, and their
families, their friends, and the

1235.text:
members of our faculty and staff
who are gathered here today.

1239.text:
Each of you has played a vital
role in making this day

1242.text:
possible. Thank you all for
that. Now, I know this morning

1246.text:
is about you, but I want to
extend a personal and heartfelt

1250.text:
thank you to Doug Orr.
Chancellor Orr has been a member

1254.text:
of our Board of Trustees for
nearly 7 years where he has

1258.text:
brought his wisdom and expertise
to bear many times during his

1261.text:
tenure. He was the co-chair on
the Search Committee that

1264.text:
successfully concluded with the
election of Mary Grant to be the

1268.text:
University's next chancellor
beginning in January. For all

1271.text:
that, he deserves countless
thanks, but it doesn't end

1274.text:
there. We are so appreciative of
Doug's willingness to step up

1278.text:
and serve as our interim
chancellor, a commitment he made

1281.text:
on short notice, and during an
extraordinarily busy time in his

1285.text:
life as he was in the process of
releasing and promoting his new

1290.text:
book, “Wayfaring Strangers.” His
calling to higher education is

1295.text:
unparalleled. Please join me in
thanking Chancellor Doug Orr for

1298.text:
his leadership during this time
of transition.

1309.text:
Graduates, at UNC Asheville, we
know that the value of a public

1313.text:
liberal arts education is
measured not only by the return

1316.text:
on the investment made by our
citizens, and our students and

1321.text:
parents but also by the value of
education as a public good.

1326.text:
A public good that is created
when we graduate students with

1328.text:
sharpened critical thinking
skills honed by undergraduate

1332.text:
research and leadership skills
born of service learning.

1336.text:
Students who are adaptable, who
can face change on the fly and

1340.text:
who are ready to continue on a
journey of lifelong learning as

1345.text:
you contribute to societies in
any number of ways. Chancellor

1351.text:
Orr's example is one I would
commend to you graduates as you

1355.text:
go forward from here. Step up
when you are asked. Take on that

1359.text:
leadership role, regardless of
the complications. Regardless of

1363.text:
the inconvenience. Try something
new. You have learned the skills

1368.text:
here at UNC Asheville to help
you figure out what to do next;

1372.text:
how to solve the problems you
haven't even thought about yet,

1376.text:
create new answers, make things
work. Leadership takes many

1380.text:
forms. It can be the loving,
quiet leadership of motherhood

1384.text:
and fatherhood. Or it can be the
leadership displayed when taking

1388.text:
charge of a crisis and helping
others find their way through.

1393.text:
The secret is to embrace each
situation with energy and

1398.text:
enthusiasm. So now, with that
energy and enthusiasm you have

1403.text:
successfully completed another
stage of your life. You are

1406.text:
ready to step forward into the
future, knowing that, as has

1411.text:
been the case here at your
university, your family, your

1414.text:
friends, your colleagues will be
with you. Congratulations.

1426.text:
It is now my pleasure to welcome
to the podium Tiffany Drummond

1429.text:
Armstrong, Chair of the National
Alumni Council, to welcome you

1433.text:
to the ranks of the UNC
Asheville alumni.

1442.text:
>> Tiffany Drummond Armstrong:
Good morning and greetings on

1445.text:
behalf of the National Alumni
Council. I'm honored to be here,

1449.text:
addressing you on this
incredibly important day in your

1452.text:
life. My husband and I had the
opportunity to cross the UNCA

1458.text:
stage to receive our hard-earned
diplomas and that day was much

1463.text:
more than a springboard into
life. It's been a part of who

1467.text:
we are ever since. We recently
moved. We changed cities after

1472.text:
13 years, years that took us
through graduate school, well

1477.text:
into our careers of education
and nonprofit management,

1481.text:
community leadership positions
and some humbling accolades. As

1485.text:
you can imagine, that's quite a
move. And after that many years,

1490.text:
moving to a new city, to a new
house with new jobs, we packed,

1495.text:
we purged, we stored all of our
stuff for a few months and now

1499.text:
we're unpacking. Through this
process we've come across items

1503.text:
of great sentimental value and
others that are less memorable.

1508.text:
We've hand-wrapped fragile
treasures and we've given away

1511.text:
things that were no longer
needed. In fact, a lot of things

1515.text:
are still in storage and there
are boxes upon boxes in my

1518.text:
garage. I can't find my favorite
sweater. I don't know where my

1521.text:
winter boots are. But one thing
that I always could put my hands

1525.text:
on was also the first thing that
decorated my new office, and

1529.text:
that's my framed UNC Asheville
diploma. It reminds me of my

1532.text:
days on campus, the friends I
made, the professors I had -

1537.text:
especially, the ones that
challenged me, made me work

1540.text:
harder than I thought possible.
It's one of my most treasured

1544.text:
items because it represents
the effort I put into getting my

1547.text:
degree. As I enter this new
phase of my personal and

1551.text:
professional life, my diploma is
a constant reminder that I'm

1555.text:
prepared for what lies ahead
because of the foundation built

1558.text:
at UNC Asheville. This
experience will almost certainly

1563.text:
happen to each of you. More than
a decade from now you will

1568.text:
remember being a student on
campus - walking through the

1571.text:
fallen maple leaves, studying in
your favorite spot in the

1575.text:
library, dorm life, hanging out
with your friends in the union,

1580.text:
and even sitting in the Kimmel
Arena at your commencement in

1583.text:
December 2014. All those many
years from now, will you recall

1588.text:
all the details from today? Will
you recall this speech? Maybe

1594.text:
not. But you will remember
walking across the stage, and

1597.text:
the moment that you received
your diploma and how that feels.

1603.text:
It will be one of your most
cherished memories. And that's

1606.text:
because graduating is no easy
task. Barely a quarter of all

1610.text:
the adults in North Carolina
have a college degree, much less

1613.text:
from such a rigorous university.
The reason that so many of our

1616.text:
graduates are leaders in their
fields is because this faculty

1619.text:
and staff taught us to think!
Life's tough, but here at

1624.text:
UNC Asheville you have
learned the skills needed to

1627.text:
navigate your life's path. I
credit much of my professional

1631.text:
and personal success to the
foundation and the time that I

1634.text:
had here at UNC Asheville.
For the rest of your life,

1637.text:
the university will continue
to support you and your

1639.text:
endeavors and I call upon you
to support your University.

1644.text:
Plan to engage with your
fellow alums in

1647.text:
the cities where you live. Plan
to return to campus for events

1650.text:
and celebrations. Plan now, and
I really urge you to commit now,

1656.text:
that you will give back of your
time, your expertise, and your

1659.text:
financial gifts to the
university. Because you're not

1663.text:
leaving UNC Asheville today; you
are the heart of this

1667.text:
institution. Your diploma
connects you to UNC Asheville

1671.text:
for the rest of your life. While
leadership may change, students

1676.text:
change, faculty and staff
change, the buildings change,

1680.text:
what remains constant is the
alumni. We are the past, the

1685.text:
present and the future of this
University and I encourage you

1689.text:
to come alongside your fellow
alums with purpose and passion

1693.text:
for UNC Asheville. On behalf of
the National Alumni Council and

1697.text:
all our alumni, we wish you the
very best in all your pursuits.

1700.text:
And you need to remember, you
are now and will forever be

1716.text: Now it is my great pleasure

1717.text:
to welcome UNC Asheville's
Provost and Vice Chancellor

1720.text:
for Academic Affairs Dr.
Joseph Urgo to the podium

to introduce this year's

1731.text:
>> Joe Urgo:  Good
morning and greetings

1733.text:
from the Provost's
Office and from the faculty.

1736.text:
Dr. Dwight Mullen, Professor of
Political Science-

1741.text:
-who needs no
introduction but will get one

1745.text:
nonetheless, is the 2014 Board
of Governors Excellence in

1749.text:
Teaching honoree from the
University of North Carolina

1752.text:
Asheville. To introduce Dr.
Mullen, I will echo the citation

1756.text:
he received earlier this year
when he was honored by the Board

1759.text:
of Governors. Dr. Mullen
embodies the ideal we hold for

1763.text:
faculty members on this campus:
he is a gifted teacher, an

1766.text:
active scholar, and an engaged
community leader. During his

1770.text:
thirty years at the University
of North Carolina Asheville,

1773.text:
he has taught courses that have
challenged and inspired his

1776.text:
students, he has served as a
Fulbright Senior Scholar in

1779.text:
Malawi, and he has held
leadership positions in the

1782.text:
greater Asheville community. His
students have pursued

1785.text:
undergraduate research on topics
that include racial inequality,

1789.text:
public education, the criminal
justice system, and income

1793.text:
disparities. By his own
admission, he has dedicated his

1796.text:
career to challenging
orthodoxies, making connections

1800.text:
where others have seen only
coincidence, engaging the public

1803.text:
in issues of justice, learning
from his colleagues, and

1806.text:
teaching by example. Dr.
Mullen's courses in Political

1810.text:
Science and Humanities are
nothing short of inspirational.

1814.text:
Students praise him for
challenging them to question

1816.text:
inherited concepts and beliefs,
and for allowing them (often for

1820.text:
the first time in their lives)
the intellectual independence to

1824.text:
think critically, reflectively
about themselves and their place

1827.text:
in the world. Applauding Dr.
Mullen's ability to capture

1831.text:
audience interest and create a
classroom climate based on

1834.text:
mutual trust, faculty, students,
and alumna offer such comments:

1838.text:
“No one else I have observed in
the classroom gets through to

1842.text:
all of our students the way that
he does,” and “His classroom

1845.text:
provided a safe place where we
could, talk openly and without

1848.text:
fear.” Dr. Mullen cares deeply
about his students and his

1853.text:
community. Dr. Mullen's
influence on an alumna who was

1856.text:
awarded a McCracken Fellowship
at the Graduate School of New

1859.text:
York University says despite all
the teachers and mentors she has

1863.text:
had in her life, she will
“always consider herself a

1865.text:
student of Dr. Mullen.” His life
work has gone beyond the

1869.text:
classroom, as evidenced by his
longstanding commitment to the

1872.text:
greater Asheville community,
where he has organized

1874.text:
conferences and public meetings,
delivered keynote addresses, and

1878.text:
worked tirelessly in social
justice and public education.

1882.text:
Comments from his colleagues on
campus include: “He knows how to

1885.text:
connect books and ideas with the
real everyday experience of

1889.text:
students and community people,”
and “the kind of teaching Dwight

1892.text:
Mullen does is courageous; he
not only talks the talk   but

1895.text:
walks the walk, in and out of
the classroom.” Over the years,

1900.text:
he has provided countless
opportunities for students to

1902.text:
conduct field work and
participate in community

1905.text:
initiatives, where they
personally experience the social

1908.text:
and political issues that are
shaping our nation and the

1910.text:
world. Many of these experiences
have been life changing, with

1914.text:
students indebted to Dr. Mullen
for opening their minds and

1917.text:
hearts. Dr. Mullen received two
advanced degrees in Political

1921.text:
Science from Atlanta University,
 a PhD in 1987, and an MA

1926.text:
in 1978. He received his BA in
History and Political Science

1930.text:
from Loma Linda University in
California, in 1976. It is my

1934.text:
pleasure to ask to come to the
podium, Dr. Dwight Mullen.

1973.text:
>> Dwight Mullen:  You all,
my students, I take this

1975.text:
pose not because it's just in
solidarity with demonstrations

1980.text:
happening across this weekend
across the country. I am not

1985.text:
taking this pose just because
I'm joining a crowd. I'm taking

1990.text:
this pose to remind you, and to
let you look at me, of what I

1995.text:
had to do when guns were drawn
on me in the streets of

1999.text:
Los Angeles. Who would have
thought it? And so I come to

2005.text:
you in peace. As-Salaam-Alaikum.
Shalom. To the Board of

2022.text:
the Administration, Faculty, and
the graduates and family and

2026.text:
friends, please accept my humble
thanks for the opportunity to

2034.text:
address you this day. I know
you're not here for me.

2039.text:
I understand that. This is not
my day. The day belongs to the

2045.text:
students who have accumulated
120 credit hours towards this

2050.text:
degree. At least. Many of you
went beyond that. You've

2056.text:
tolerated us. You've been
fascinated by us. You've

2059.text:
listened to our lectures. We've
listened to you. You have

2064.text:
reached this point not just
because of your efforts but also

2068.text:
because of the efforts of this
community. You've worked hard.

2073.text:
In fact, earlier this week, the
faculty voted to approve your

2077.text:
graduation. We said, they need
to get these awards. Award them

2083.text:
the degrees. And so today is the
day. Except you have one more

2090.text:
lecture. One last word from me.
Bear with me. One of the

2100.text:
greybeards. I've been here 30
years. This is my thirtieth

2105.text:
year. And I am proud to say to
you that the questions I have

2112.text:
posed to you in class constitute
the core of this last lecture.

2118.text:
I've tried through all the
different subjects to present

2122.text:
you with the most profound
questions of life. Because I

2126.text:
know that you get criticized for
the uselessness of a liberal

2129.text:
arts degree. But it's only
because you don't get it. And

2133.text:
those people who are questioning
you don't get it. Just think

2139.text:
about it. A few years ago, many
of you were just coming out of

2144.text:
middle school and high school.
You all actually thought you

2148.text:
knew the answers. Now that
you're graduating some of you

2154.text:
are beginning, in fact, I would
suspect most of you are

2157.text:
beginning to realize that
answers are transitory. What you

2162.text:
thought you knew no longer may
apply. It might even be

2166.text:
embarrassing to you. What seems
so pressing today doesn't seem

2172.text:
at all relevant as you mature
and as you grow. Many of your

2177.text:
senior level projects, for
example, were predicated first

2181.text:
not on the answers that you
provided in your final product.

2185.text:
Your senior level projects often
were based on questions that you

2191.text:
were able to formulate on your
own. That's the hard part.

2195.text:
Asking the questions, developing
the skills, and then convincing

2200.text:
the faculty of your departments
that you deserve a degree. And

2204.text:
we will hope that you will not
stop here. That you will

2207.text:
continue to question. Who am I?
Where do I come from? Where am I

2216.text:
going and why am I here? Those
are the profound questions. We

2222.text:
can't talk about all of those
today. But I want to address

2226.text:
just one, maybe two. I want you
all to grow as some of my

2232.text:
students have grown. Just one
last time. Who am I? First up,

2241.text:
let me say to you that the
answer to this question

2244.text:
allows us to begin
to address who YOU are.

2250.text:
If you can answer for
yourself, you can

2252.text:
begin to understand that others
also might have an identity.

2257.text:
That maybe that's not just
another exotic other person.

2262.text:
Maybe his name is Michael Brown.
Maybe we don't let Michael lay

2270.text:
in the street for four and a
half hours. You know him. Who am

2274.text:
I is profound because it
connects you to who you are as a

2279.text:
community. Don't ever be
dissuaded from following that

2283.text:
question. Some of you - it may
be embarrassing to you, I've

2287.text:
talked to you, I know - some of
you, a few years ago, thought

2293.text:
for sure that you could cast a
spell. That you were somehow a

2298.text:
member of Raven Claw or
Slytherin or Hufflepuff. Isn't

2302.text:
it the truth? It's the truth.
Gryffindor. Some of you tried

2308.text:
with your heart's might to cast
a spell to control the beasts

2313.text:
and mysteries of your life.
Harry Potterites. Some of you

2319.text:
claim identities, you claim
lifestyles that are totally

2323.text:
incongruent with your family and
communities. Gender roles have

2328.text:
been rejected, mountain
traditions ignored, religious

2335.text:
trappings avoided. Some of you
wouldn't even go home. These

2340.text:
choices came at a cost of the
acceptance of those who love

2343.text:
you. Answering this question of
“Who am I?” many of you have

2350.text:
been left alone and distressed.
Here at UNCA we have tried,

2355.text:
imperfectly, but we've tried to
provide an environment of safety

2360.text:
for you. Because if we allow you
the opportunities to figure out

2364.text:
who you are then possibly you
begin to discover how intimately

2370.text:
you are connected with others.
And the degree of that intimacy

2374.text:
is always up to you. It's your
choice. But be careful. As an

2380.text:
African-American man I have
found my identity to be, at

2384.text:
times, a life and death
consideration. Where do I come

2391.text:
from. A question of Origins. My
immediate ancestors were

2401.text:
veterans of the Revolutionary
War, the Civil War - I didn't

2406.text:
find anyone in World War I,
but definitely World War II,

2410.text:
and of course Korea and
Vietnam. These same family

2422.text:
lynched, imprisoned and de facto
Jim Crowed. After 200 years in

2429.text:
this country, I am here. After
200 years I'm here. Don't you

2439.text:
dare lose faith. It cannot be
allowed. But I'm not here as a

2446.text:
direct result of my efforts.
Please. It's only because of the

2452.text:
efforts of the community. For
the last 30 years, I've tried to

2457.text:
reconcile where I come from with
my presence here at UNCA. Some

2463.text:
of you have even asked me why
I'm still here. Maybe my

2467.text:
experiences can give you an
example. As graduates of this

2471.text:
university, and the reason this
question becomes so critical, is

2475.text:
because now UNCA is part of your
origins, too. I keep seeing

2482.text:
people from my classes. It's
nice. Some of you are

2488.text:
ambivalent. Really could care
less. You're torn between

2493.text:
positive and negative, being
from UNCA, being here. Others of

2498.text:
you have been profoundly
changed. You are not the same

2503.text:
person you were when you came
here and you were happy for your

2505.text:
experiences and have every
intention of staying in contact.

2509.text:
Still others of you are going to
use this degree as just proof

2515.text:
for a higher job, just more
money, it's just self-serving.

2521.text:
That's okay. That's okay. But
remember this, regardless of

2526.text:
your purposes, this is not an
accident. Your place here has

2532.text:
significance. It is with meaning
that you are graduating. Your

2538.text:
time here was well spent because
now you're part of a greater

2543.text:
whole. And not just for being
part of the pack, the Bulldogs.

2549.text:
But also because you joined that
one-tenth of one percent, if not

2554.text:
less, of the world's population
that has gotten to your point.

2558.text:
Your education, your levels. You
are the elite. You are the top.

2565.text:
It carries with it
responsibilities. You know, for

2570.text:
many years, I didn't talk about
where I came from. It was too

2574.text:
incongruent with my current
surroundings. I mean, come on.

2579.text:
People looked at me like maybe I
don't belong here and other

2582.text:
people looked at me like you
belong here because you are

2585.text:
exotic. You're different.
Students need to be exposed to

2589.text:
that. And on my part, let me be
honest with you now, on my part,

2596.text:
I really had no intention of
staying. I had just returned

2600.text:
from Nigeria and I been teaching
in university life there. And

2606.text:
UNCA was the only white campus I
applied to. My intent was to go

2610.text:
to a Historically Black College
or University. I had promised to

2614.text:
go home. I had promised to
return to the places that

2618.text:
sourced me. I thought this place
was a stopover. I thought it was

2625.text:
a temporary job while I looked
for a permanent place to raise

2627.text:
my family. And here I am, 30
years later. I actually thought

2635.text:
that I did not escape Watts just
to be on a small white campus

2641.text:
who had been forced to make
token gestures towards

2646.text:
desegregation. I often thought,
“What am I doing here?” ”Why am

2658.text:
I here?” “Where am I going with
this?” It only occurred to me

2664.text:
recently to show you the path
that we all take in our

2667.text:
educations. It only occurred to
me recently that despite this

2674.text:
unpredictability, despite the
discomfort, there are rewards

2679.text:
and recognitions. Despite
sometimes being rejected for who

2684.text:
I am and where I've chosen to
be. This is my home. This has

2691.text:
become the community in which I
have given the greater part of

2694.text:
my life. Now many of you already
call the mountains your home.

2698.text:
You were born and raised here.
You've adopted the region as

2700.text:
your own. If you're going to
leave, you plan on coming back.

2704.text:
This is your home. That was not
my intent. But it has become the

2708.text:
fact of my life. How else can I
explain my presence? How else

2713.text:
can I justify the last
assignment you will get from

2718.text:
UNCA? You know, with a lecture
comes an assignment. I intended

2726.text:
on getting what I wanted out of
this place and moving on, too.

2730.text:
But it was wrong. It did not
happen. Now if you think you

2735.text:
can't make a difference, think
again. Not only can you make a

2741.text:
difference, let me pose to you
that you must make a difference,

2749.text:
that there is no choice about
making a difference.

2753.text:
The question is will it be
positive or negative. Because

2757.text:
the choices you make will save
lives. How else do you think I'm

2763.text:
standing here? People like you
stepped up and said

2788.text:
: And it won't
end with you. This is not

2792.text:
easy work. We're not talking
satin sheets and crystal stairs

2799.text:
-we are making quilts. We're
constructing a viable workplace.

2806.text:
This workplace constitutes the
future. You will build the

2813.text:
twenty-first century. And so, my
assignment to you is this:

2820.text:
Start at home. Look around you.
And say to yourself, are you

2828.text:
empirically minded? Are you
Bachelors of Science? Say to

2831.text:
yourself, we got 3%
African-American students here.

2837.text:
The population of the state is
22%. What's wrong with this

2841.text:
picture? Because if we can open
the doors for that population.

2847.text:
We figured out how to open the
doors for poor Appalachian

2850.text:
whites and for Native Americans
and for Latino communities all

2853.text:
over the country. UNCA will be
set to survive the 21st Century

2858.text:
because there is no choice. It's
coming. Help us get ready for

2865.text:
it. And so, the improbability of
a poor boy from Watts standing

2870.text:
before you giving a Commencement
Address no longer becomes an

2875.text:
anomaly. It becomes a work of
your life. And on anticipation

2883.text:
of that, I thank you. Good
People, I give you the graduates

2929.text:
for your eloquence, your
example and for making such a

2933.text:
profound difference in your
30-year stopover. We appreciate

2939.text:
so much you and your example and
we know you will stay connected

2943.text:
to this wonderful community.
Now, it is with great pleasure

2950.text:
that I welcome Provost and Vice
Chancellor for Academic Affairs,

2954.text:
Dr. Joe Urgo, back to the podium
for the conferring of degrees.

2968.text:
>> Urgo:  Since 1991,
UNC Asheville has awarded

2972.text:
a Master's degree in the Liberal
Arts. A unique offering in

2976.text:
Higher Education, the
interdisciplinary Master of

2979.text:
Liberal Arts and Sciences
program challenges students to

2982.text:
explore the interconnectedness
of the human condition.

2985.text:
From arts and humanities to the
natural and social sciences, the

2988.text:
MLAS degree is an extraordinary
and important component of UNC

2993.text:
Asheville's liberal arts
mission. Will the candidates for

2996.text:
the Master of Liberal Arts and
Sciences Degree please stand?

3011.text:
Chancellor Orr, these students
have completed all of the

3014.text:
requirements for the Masters
Degree and have been so

3016.text:
certified by the faculty and the
Registrar. I present them to you

3028.text:
of your successful
completion of the course of

3030.text:
study and your fulfillment of
requirements, by vote of this

3035.text:
University's Faculty and with
the approval of the Board of

3038.text:
Trustees and the concurrence of
the Board of Governors, and by

3043.text:
virtue of the authority vested
in me by these boards and the

3046.text:
State of North Carolina, I
hereby confer upon you the

3050.text:
degree of Master of Liberal
Arts. Will you please come

3137.text:
Will all of
the candidates for the

3153.text:
Chancellor Orr, these students
have completed all of the

3156.text:
requirements for the
Baccalaureate Degree and have

3159.text:
been so certified by the faculty
and the Registrar. I present

3162.text:
them to you for the awarding of
degrees.

3170.text:
>> Orr:  In recognition
of your successful completion

3174.text:
of the course of study and your
fulfillment of requirements,

3177.text:
by vote of the University
Faculty and with the approval

3179.text:
of the UNC Asheville Board of
Trustees and the concurrence

3183.text:
of the UNC Board of Governors,
and by virtue of the authority

3187.text:
vested in me by these boards and
the State of North Carolina,

3192.text:
I confer upon each of you, as
appropriate, the degree of

3362.text:
Stephanie Brown Case
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

3435.text:
Justin Max English
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

3487.text:

MAGNA CUM LAUDE

MAGNA CUM LAUDE

MAGNA CUM LAUDE

SUMMA CUM LAUDE

3620.text:

SUMMA CUM LAUDE

3754.text:
Kyle Foster Moore
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

3832.text:

SUMMA CUM LAUDE

3846.text:
Charlotte Anna Rapp
SUMMA CUM LAUDE

3888.text:
Erich Woodward Reinhard
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

3961.text:

SUMMA CUM LAUDE

4083.text:
And now, the Bachelor
of Fine Arts

4109.text:
Jennifer Patricia O'Connell
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4116.text:
For the Bachelor of
Science and Engineering,

4119.text:
a degree awarded
jointly by UNC Asheville and

4149.text:
Nagi Jassem Al-Fouzan
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4285.text:
Rose Ellen Dunnington
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4407.text:
Bastian Dai Herr
SUMMA CUM LAUDE

4495.text:
Mead Thomas Lyons
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4545.text:
Sydney Carolyn McGary
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4701.text:
Christopher Sean Tilstra
MAGNA CUM LAUDE

4742.text:

SUMMA CUM LAUDE

4776.text:
Chancellor Orr.
Robert Evan Coin completed

4781.text:
all degree requirements and was
awarded his diploma

4784.text:
posthumously. We recognize
Robbie's accomplishments here

4787.text:
today as a member of this
graduating class.

4822.text:
>> Orr:  As we conclude the
December commencement exercises

4827.text:
at the University of North
Carolina Asheville, I want to

4831.text:
welcome all of you and thank you
for all that you have done.

4836.text:
Let's just take a minute if we
will, this is not even in the

4839.text:
program and just thank and
applaud the family members, the

4843.text:
supporters, the friends, who
have supported this wonderful

4864.text:
Let's call this a
parting but not a

4866.text:
farewell. I'd like to share
with you a poem by Nancy Wood.

4871.text:
“A long time I have lived with
you and learned and now we must

4876.text:
be going, separately to be
together. Perhaps I shall be the

4882.text:
wind to blur your smooth waters
and to stir you to try new

4886.text:
paths. Perhaps I shall be the
star to guide you on certain

4891.text:
wings so that you have direction
in the night. Perhaps I shall be

4897.text:
the fire to separate your
thoughts so that you never give

4902.text:
up. Perhaps I shall be the rain
to open the earth so that your

4908.text:
seed may fall. Perhaps I shall
be the snow to let your blossoms

4912.text:
sleep so that you may bloom in
the Spring. Perhaps I shall be

4917.text:
that mountain stream to play a
song on the rocks so that you

4920.text:
are not alone. And perhaps I
shall be a new mountain, so that

4926.text:
you always, always have a home”"
So, friends, supporters, but

4935.text:
most important of all graduates
we celebrate you. Subsequently

4941.text:
we will all move to the quad and
celebrate this wonderful

4944.text:
occasion. You will find in your
program signs outside of each

4947.text:
building to help you locate
faculty members from your

4951.text:
academic departments. Audience,
I ask that you please remain

4955.text:
seated until the recessional is
completed the Platform Party,

5006.text:
By virtue of the
authority vested

5007.text:
in me by the UNC Asheville
Board of Trustees,

5010.text:
the UNC Board of Governors, and
the State of North Carolina, I

5014.text:
now proclaim you graduates of
the University of North Carolina

5019.text:
at Asheville. Newest alumni, it
is that time. As tradition goes,

5025.text:
please move your tassels to the
left, and you are now graduates.

5083.text:
Michelle Arielle McIntyre
back to the podium

5086.text:
to lead us in the singing of
our alma mater. So would you

5089.text:
please stand as we sing the alma
mater. The words are printed in

5116.text:
Hail UNCA. Learning
be your watchword,

5126.text:
Greatness be your way. High
 upon the mountains, In the

5138.text:
Land of Sky, Stands our Alma
Mater, Lift your voices high.

5152.text:
Noble Alma Mater, Hear our
words of praise. May we love

5165.text:
and honor you, Until
the end of days.
